title: Germany calls for changes to EU’s human rights safeguards so migrants can be returned to ‘unsafe’ states | National Post
text:
Germany calls for changes to EU’s human rights safeguards so migrants can be returned to ‘unsafe’ states The Telegraph | February 22, 2017 10:45 AM ET FarkIt 
Germany has called for the European Union to scrap human rights safeguards so migrants can be deported to countries currently considered unsafe. 
Under the plan, asylum seekers who cross the Mediterranean illegally could be sent back to “transit” countries such as Libya, Tunisia, and Algeria while their cases are considered. 
The proposals come as a leaked German government paper warned that as many as 5.9 million people could seek to enter the EU from countries around the Mediterranean. 
The plans would open the way for migrants to be held in internment camps in North Africa while their asylum applications are processed. Related Angela Merkel disowns plan by her party to stop migrants ’ children from holding two passports 
But they are likely to prove controversial amid warnings that asylum seekers’ safety cannot be guaranteed in countries suffering from their own internal conflicts — such as Libya. 
EU member states are currently debating reforms to the bloc’s asylum system so it can cope with any repeat of the 2015 refugee crisis. 
A policy document put forward by Germany calls for a “crisis mechanism” that would “only spring into action in the event of a mass influx.” 
France denied reports that French officials also worked on the paper. The mechanism would be modelled on the migrant deal with Turkey.
